questions.text: A 40-year-old male comes with an intracapsular fracture of femur. What is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
Operative Treatment Principles for Fractures

Fracture Reduction

  • Timeliness: Fracture reduction should occur promptly to minimize the risk of osteonecrosis. The quality of fracture reduction is also critical.
  • Reduction Maneuver:
    • Perform hip flexion with gentle traction and external rotation to disengage the fragments.
    • Follow with slow extension and internal rotation to achieve reduction.
    • Confirm reduction with AP and lateral imaging.
  • Guidelines for Acceptable Reduction:
    • AP View: Valgus or anatomical alignment should be observed.
    • Lateral View: Maintain anteversion while avoiding posterior translation of the fracture surfaces.
    • Assessment of Posterior Comminution: Ensure thorough evaluation.

Internal Fixation

  • (Choice B) : Multiple Screw Fixation
    • Most accepted method; screws should cross the fracture site for compression.
    • Typically, three parallel screws are used. Additional screws do not enhance stability and may penetrate the joint.
    • Configuration: Screws should be arranged in an inverted triangular configuration with one screw adjacent to the inferior femoral neck and another to the posterior femoral neck.
    • Avoid inserting screws distal to the lesser trochanter to prevent stress risers and potential subtrochanteric fractures.
  • (Choice A) : Sliding-Screw and Side Plate Devices:
    • If utilized, a second pin or screw should be placed superiorly to control rotation during screw insertion.
    • These devices improve resistance to shear forces, particularly in high Pauwel angle fractures.

Prosthetic Replacement (Choice C)

  • Advantages Over Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF):
    • Allows for faster full weight-bearing.
    • Eliminates risks of nonunion, osteonecrosis, and failure of fixation (over 20% to 40% of ORIF cases may require secondary surgery).
  • Disadvantages:
    • More extensive procedure with greater blood loss.

Primary Total Hip Replacement : (Choice D)

  • Recent interest in total hip replacement for acute treatment of displaced femoral neck fractures has increased specially in cases with pre-existing arthritis.
  • This approach is becoming standard for active patients.
  • Studies indicate better functional results compared to hemiarthroplasty and internal fixation.
  • Eliminates potential acetabular erosion associated with hemiarthroplasty.

Key takeaways :

For a case of neck femur fracture

  • If age is less than 60 yrs >>>>>> Fixation with Screws or DHS
  • If age is more than 60 yrs without pre-existing arthritis and not very active lifestyle >>>>> Bipolar hemiarthroplasty
  • If age is more than 60 yrs with pre-existing arthritis and active lifestyle >>>>> Total hip replacement.

questions.text: During walking the hip bone on the side of the suspended leg is raised by the action of which muscle present in the supporting leg?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of Balance While Standing on One Leg

When a person stands on both legs, the center of gravity (COG) is positioned between the two feet, forming a stable base. However, when one leg is lifted off the ground, the COG shifts outside the base, now supported by a single foot. This shift causes the pelvis on the opposite side to dip, which the body counteracts by tilting the pelvis toward the standing leg.

Role of the Abductor Muscles

The tilting mechanism is facilitated by the effective contraction of the hip abductor muscles, primarily the gluteus medius. These muscles help maintain balance by preventing excessive pelvic drop.

The Abductor Mechanism as a Lever System

The function of the abductor muscles can be understood through a lever system:

  • Fulcrum: The center of the hip joint
  • Load: The body's weight, which exerts a downward force attempting to tilt the pelvis
  • Effort: The abductor muscle force, acting through the lever arm (the neck of the femur) to counteract the load

Causes of Abductor Mechanism Failure

If the abductor mechanism is ineffective, it results in pelvic dipping on the opposite (normal) side. This failure can occur due to:

  1. Loss of Fulcrum - e.g., hip dislocation or destruction of the femoral head
  2. Ineffective Lever-Arm (Femoral Neck Dysfunction) - e.g., fracture of the femoral neck
  3. Weak Abductor Muscles - e.g., muscle weakness due to polio or a shortened lever arm (as seen in coxa vara)

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Gluteus maximus - Incorrect
While the gluteus maximus is important for hip extension and stability, it does not primarily control pelvic tilt during walking. Its main role is in movements like climbing stairs and rising from a seated position.

Choice C: Obturator internus - Incorrect
The obturator internus is primarily responsible for lateral rotation of the hip. It does not have a significant role in stabilizing the pelvis while standing on one leg.

Choice D: Quadratus lumborum - Incorrect
The quadratus lumborum helps in lateral flexion of the spine and assists in stabilizing the lower back. While it can compensate in cases of pelvic instability, it is not the main muscle responsible for preventing pelvic drop.

Key Takeaway:

The gluteus medius is the primary muscle responsible for maintaining pelvic stability when standing on one leg. Weakness in this muscle can lead to Trendelenburg gait, where the pelvis drops on the opposite side during walking.

questions.text: Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve leads to:-
questions.solution:
Radial Nerve and Its Branches

Before crossing the elbow in front of the lateral condyle, the radial nerve divides into two branches:

  1. Superficial Branch (Primarily Sensory)
    • Travels alongside the radial artery into the forearm
    • Provides sensory innervation
  2. Deep Branch (Primarily Motor)
    • Innervates the extensor carpi radialis brevis and supinator
    • Pierces the supinator and emerges in the posterior forearm
    • Becomes the posterior interosseous nerve, which further divides into branches that supply the extensor muscles of the forearm

Functions of Key Extensor Muscles

  1. Extensor Digitorum
    • Function: Extends the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints
    • Clinical Relevance: Paralysis leads to "finger drop", preventing MCP joint extension
    • Important Note: Patients may still appear to "extend" their fingers at the interphalangeal joints, but this movement is performed by the lumbricals, not the extensor digitorum
  2. Extensor Pollicis Longus
    • Function: Extends the interphalangeal (IP) joint of the thumb
    • Examination Method:
      • Stabilize the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb
      • Ask the patient to extend the interphalangeal joint

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Loss of extension of the wrist - Incorrect
The posterior interosseous nerve does not innervate the extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL), which is responsible for wrist extension. Since ECRL is innervated by the radial nerve before it gives off the PIN, wrist extension remains intact, though it may be weak.

Choice C: Wrist drop - Incorrect
Complete radial nerve injury (proximal to the elbow) causes wrist drop due to paralysis of all wrist extensors. However, posterior interosseous nerve injury occurs distal to the origin of extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL), which means wrist extension is weakened but not completely lost. Thus, wrist drop does not occur.

Choice D: Loss of supination - Incorrect
The biceps brachii is the primary supinator of the forearm and is supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve. The supinator muscle, which receives innervation from the deep branch of the radial nerve, contributes to supination but is not the sole muscle responsible. Therefore, supination is weakened but not completely lost in PIN injury.

Key Takeaway:

  • Posterior interosseous nerve injury leads to:
    • Loss of extension of the digits (Finger Drop)
  • It does not cause:
    • Complete wrist drop (Wrist extension is weakened but preserved)
    • Complete loss of supination (Biceps brachii compensates)

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of back pain, stiffness and recurrent episode of UTIs Imaging was done suggestive of sacroiliitis. Which of the following HLA is commonly involved?
questions.solution:
Ankylosing Spondylitis: Etiology and Clinical Features

Etiology

The exact cause of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) remains unknown. However, a strong genetic association has been identified with the HLA-B27 marker:

  • HLA-B27 prevalence in the general population: Less than 1%
  • HLA-B27 prevalence in AS patients: More than 85%

Pathology and Progression

  • The sacroiliac joints are typically the first to be affected, leading to sacroiliitis.
  • The disease progresses upwards from the lumbar spine to involve the rest of the vertebral column.

Clinical Presentation

  • Age group: Young adults, typically between 15-30 years
  • Gender: More common in males
  • Symptoms:
    • Gradual onset of lower back pain
    • Progressive stiffness in the spine

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: HLA DQB1 - Incorrect
HLA-DQB1 is associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus and celiac disease, not ankylosing spondylitis.

Choice B: HLA DR3 -; Incorrect
HLA-DR3 is linked to autoimmune diseases such as type 1 diabetes, Graves' disease, and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It has no significant association with ankylosing spondylitis.

Choice D: HLA DR4 - Incorrect
HLA-DR4 is strongly associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), another form of inflammatory arthritis, but not with ankylosing spondylitis.

Key Takeaway:

  • HLA-B27 is the genetic marker most commonly associated with ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Sacroiliitis is an early and characteristic radiologic finding in AS.
  • AS predominantly affects young males and presents with chronic back pain and stiffness.

Osteoporotic Fractures: Key Points

  1. Fracture Risk Assessment
    • The World Health Organization (WHO) Fracture Risk Assessment Tool (FRAX) estimates the 10-year risk of hip fracture in individuals.
  2. Bisphosphonate-Associated Stress Fractures
    • Low-energy stress fractures can occur in patients undergoing bisphosphonate treatment for osteoporosis.
    • These fractures are typically characterized by:
      • Cortical thickening
      • Transverse fracture pattern
      • Minimal comminution
  3. Proximal Humerus Fracture as a Predictor
    • A proximal humerus fracture is a strong indicator of an increased risk for a subsequent low-energy hip fracture.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Fracture rehabilitation assessment - Incorrect
FRAX does not assess rehabilitation. Rehabilitation assessment involves functional recovery, pain management, and physiotherapy after a fracture.

Choice C: Fracture repair assessment - Incorrect
FRAX is not related to fracture healing or bone repair. Bone healing is evaluated using radiographic and clinical assessments.

Choice D: Fracture reduction assessment - Incorrect
FRAX does not measure fracture reduction. Reduction assessment is performed during fracture management and surgery, evaluating proper bone alignment and fixation.

Key Takeaway:

  • FRAX estimates the 10-year risk of major osteoporotic fractures.
  • It helps guide osteoporosis management and preventive interventions.
  • It does not assess fracture healing, reduction, or rehabilitation.
